Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned varied Spanish vocabulary, grammar, and speaking and writing skills. I also learned about Spanish culture.
I learned basic conversational Spanish. I can now understand Narcos without subtitles.

I became more confident in my Spanish speaking abilities, and I learned much about how Spanish language is structured. For me, the most important thing was that I was able to start understanding my professor in class verbally, and through that I was able to get a better grasp on Spanish grammar which made all the difference on how I view my capabilities in Spanish.
I developed a more in depth knowledge of the Spanish language. I was able to improve my speaking, listening, and comprehension through out the course.
I really developed my language and communication skills in this course.

The course covered various aspects of the Spanish language (speaking, reading, writing) very well. It was interesting and engaging, and the instructor was very good. The class made me eager to master the Spanish language. The course could be improved with more prompt grading - assignments took a very long time to be returned. More in-class writing assignments would also be useful to improve writing skills.

So, I can appreciate that languages are taught in seminar form. This fosters more personal interaction between students and other students as well as students and the professor (thereby supposedly increasing the overall participation of each student bc they feel more invested). That being said, I don't know if meeting every day and only for 50 minutes works super well? I don't know, I'll probably take the intensive classes next semester which don't meet every day, but do meet for 2-3 hours. That could just be a weird preference of mine though.
The required books are ridiculously expensive and you only use half the book for L2.

For the strengths, I think that the course has an extremely thought-out curriculum that has various components that complement each other greatly. I really appreciated having a course catalog that went through day-by-day what we were doing, and with the matching homework assignments included as well, so it meant that no assignment or big project was ever really a surprise. I am not sure how you could make it stronger, but I know my professor struggled with keeping on top of all of the grades, so maybe the course could try to accommodate that a bit more.
The course was very well organized and spread out the learning material well through the semester.
The course was very organized and the professor very competent.  It moved somewhat quickly but that was fine.
Yes, I would. It was a great language course. The workload was heavy at times, but it was manageable.

This is how I would talk to another student: Like, you need to take a language credit. For a person like me who thought they were done with language stuff in high school (and didn't take language up until this point at Yale) that's a bit of an adjustment. Get your language requirement out of the way your Freshmen year. There's nothing particularly exhilarating about learning the subjunctive mood in Spanish, but the professors do their best to be as engaging as possible. Go in with a positive attitude and this class will fun.
I would not, because the books are too expensive. It's a shame because the course itself was great.
Yes I would because I think this course is so important for anyone who wants a better understanding of both Spanish language and Spanish culture.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is still introductory to Spanish, but also a higher learning level for advancement.
Yes, the professor was great, and the material engaging.
